results_summary: Methionine was identified as the first limiting amino acid in Acacia colei. CEC incorporation in casein diets suppressed methionine-induced growth and negatively affected plasma amino acid levels.
population_specificity: Wistar rats
effective_dosage: Not specified for casein (CEC-incorporated casein diets used)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether casein, as a placebo, had any effect on exercise tolerance and quality of life in COPD patients compared to pressurized whey supplementation.
results_summary: Casein supplementation showed clinically significant improvement in the Dyspnea and Mastery scales of the CRQ at week 16, but no significant increase in CET time or systemic inflammatory/oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: 22 patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a leucine-enriched, high-protein medical food (containing casein and whey) stimulates muscle protein synthesis more effectively than a conventional casein-based medical food in cancer patients.
results_summary: The leucine-enriched supplement significantly increased muscle protein synthesis (FSR) in cancer patients, while the conventional casein-based supplement did not. Plasma leucine levels were also higher with the experimental supplement.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with radiographic evidence of disease, either before treatment or 4 weeks after treatment completion/halting.
effective_dosage: Experimental group: 40 g protein (casein and whey) with 10% free leucine; control group: 24 g casein protein.
study_duration: Acute effects measured 5 hours after ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers sought to compare the effects of soy supplementation versus casein placebo on abdominal fat, glucose metabolism, and inflammatory markers in obese postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Casein was used as a placebo and showed no significant effects on glucose metabolism, inflammatory markers, or adipokines compared to soy supplementation. The study did not report any adverse effects from casein.
population_specificity: Obese, postmenopausal Caucasian and African American women (n=33 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whey protein, casein, and glucose supplementation on blood pressure, vascular function, and inflammatory markers in overweight/obese individuals.
results_summary: Casein supplementation significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure at weeks 6 and 12 compared to baseline, though vascular function improvements were not as pronounced as with whey protein. No significant changes in inflammatory markers were observed.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese men and women (mean BMI 31.3 ± 0.8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whey protein supplementation on body composition, lipids, insulin, and glucose levels against casein and glucose (control) in overweight/obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in body composition or serum glucose in the casein group compared to the control or whey protein group. Casein did not show significant improvements in fasting lipids or insulin levels, unlike whey protein.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese men and women with a mean age of 48.4 years and mean BMI of 31.3 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and therapeutic benefits of a gluten-free, casein-free (GFCF) diet in autistic children.
results_summary: The study found that the GFCF diet was safe and showed therapeutic benefits for autistic children, though the trials were limited in number, sample size, and indicated potential bias. Larger cohort studies are needed for further insight.
population_specificity: Autistic children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if casein supplementation could elevate serum IGF-I levels as early as one week after administration, compared to whey protein and whey protein combined with essential amino acids, in women with recent hip fractures.
results_summary: The study found that casein supplementation significantly elevated serum IGF-I levels (+37.3 µg/L) after just 7 days, with similar effects observed for whey protein and whey protein combined with essential amino acids. No further significant increase in IGF-I was observed from day 7 to day 28.
population_specificity: 45 women with recent hip fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the benefits and safety of a gluten-free and casein-free (GFCF) diet in children diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of a GFCF diet on autism core symptoms, functional level, or behavioral difficulties in children with ASD. However, the diet might trigger gastrointestinal adverse effects.
population_specificity: Children aged 3 to 17 years diagnosed with ASD, with or without comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the scientific evidence for nutritional interventions, including casein-free diets, in children and adolescents with Autism Spectrum Disorder.
results_summary: The review found mixed results, with 10 studies reporting positive associations between casein-free diets and improved symptoms, while 8 studies found no significant association. The overall evidence was insufficient to strongly support the use of casein-free diets for autism.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with Autism Spectrum Disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of re-assembled casein micelles (rCM) on vitamin D3 (VD3) against thermal and oxidative degradation, and to assess VD3 bioavailability in rCM.
results_summary: VD3 encapsulated in rCM showed superior stability under thermal treatment (80°C, 1 min) and cold storage (28 days) compared to synthetic emulsifiers or unencapsulated VD3. Ultra-high-pressure homogenization further enhanced stability, and bioavailability of VD3 in rCM was at least as high as that of Tween-80-emulsified VD3.
population_specificity: 87 human volunteers in a randomized double-blinded placebo-controlled clinical study.
effective_dosage: Single dose of 50,000 IU VD3 encapsulated in rCM, administered in 1% fat milk.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention; stability assessed over 28 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on dietary approaches, including casein-free diets, for managing gastrointestinal and behavioral symptoms in individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASD).
results_summary: The study found that gluten-free/casein-free diets, among other dietary approaches, generally demonstrated improved gastrointestinal and associated behavioral symptoms in individuals with ASD, though research on dietary interventions is limited and results are mixed.
population_specificity: Individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and associated gastrointestinal issues.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effects of therapeutic diets, including casein-free diets, on autism spectrum disorder.
results_summary: Among the studies reviewed, 4 clinical studies examined gluten/casein-free diets, with 2 showing favorable outcomes in children with autism. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Children with autism spectrum disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of medical nutrition therapies, including casein-free diets, on alleviating symptoms of autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The study found that casein-free diets, among other nutritional interventions, may play a role in alleviating ASD symptoms, though further controlled trials are needed for definitive recommendations.
population_specificity: Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a casein-free diet as a treatment for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and autism spectrum disorder, focusing on potential mechanisms like the microbiome-gut-brain axis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that elimination diets, including casein-free diets, may have potential benefits for neurodevelopmental disorders, but the evidence is discussed in the context of broader mechanisms rather than specific outcomes. The microbiome-gut-brain axis is highlighted as a key candidate mechanism.
population_specificity: Individuals with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and autism spectrum disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the safety and efficacy of casein-free diet as a complementary treatment for behavioral and gastrointestinal symptoms in autism.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on casein-free diet, only mentioning it as one of several therapies examined for autism-related symptoms.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with autism experiencing behavioral and gastrointestinal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a casein-free diet in treating autism, including its effects on core symptoms and comorbid issues.
results_summary: Some parents reported improvements in autism symptoms (20-29%), but intervention trials were contradictory and inconclusive. The evidence supporting the diet's therapeutic value was deemed limited and weak.
population_specificity: Children with autism spectrum disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential impact of a casein-free diet on autism spectrum disorders, focusing on differing responses and underlying biological correlates.
results_summary: The study suggests that a casein-free diet may variably impact autism presentation, with evidence of best- and non-response subgroups, and highlights potential biological mechanisms like immune response and gut microbiota.
population_specificity: Individuals with autism spectrum disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of gluten and casein supplementation on maladaptive behavior, gastrointestinal symptom severity, and urinary I-FABP excretion in children with ASD.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in maladaptive behavior, gastrointestinal symptoms, or urinary I-FABP excretion between the gluten-casein and placebo groups after one week of supplementation. The observed changes in behavior were not significant and may have been influenced by additional therapies.
population_specificity: 74 children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) exhibiting severe maladaptive behavior and increased urinary I-FABP.

study_goal: To review evidence associating intestinal barrier dysfunction with CNS disorders and assess the potential impact of gluten-free casein-free diets on behavioral symptoms in autism spectrum disorders.
results_summary: Some reports suggest gluten-free casein-free diets may normalize intestinal permeability markers in autism spectrum disorders, but no adequately controlled studies demonstrate behavioral symptom improvement. Evidence for altered intestinal permeability in CNS disorders is limited and inconclusive.
population_specificity: Individuals with autism spectrum disorders and schizophrenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential benefits of a casein-free diet in a subgroup of schizophrenia patients, considering gut-brain axis interactions and immune dysregulation.
results_summary: The study suggests that a casein-free diet may benefit a significant subgroup of schizophrenia patients by addressing gut barrier dysfunction, inflammation, and metabolic syndrome, though specific efficacy data are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with schizophrenia, particularly those with gastrointestinal barrier dysfunction, food antigen sensitivity, or metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten- and casein-free diet in children with autism spectrum disorder and identify factors predicting positive responses.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in core and peripheral functioning between dietary and non-dietary participants, with responders showing improvements in inattention and hyperactivity. Age (7–9 years) was the strongest predictor of positive response, and the presence of a urine compound (trans-indolyl-3-acryloylglycine) may warrant further investigation.
population_specificity: Children diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a casein-free diet as a newer, less-researched treatment option for developmental delays in children.
results_summary: The abstract mentions casein-free diets as a newer treatment with less research support, implying limited evidence for efficacy in addressing developmental delays. No specific results regarding its effects are provided.
population_specificity: Children with developmental delays.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a gluten-free, casein-free diet, later combined with a ketogenic diet, on autism symptoms, epilepsy, and cognitive-behavioral outcomes in a child with autism and epilepsy.
results_summary: The child showed marked improvement in autistic and medical symptoms on a gluten-free, casein-free diet, and further seizure control and cognitive-behavioral benefits when the diet was combined with a ketogenic regimen. Secondary benefits included resolution of obesity and significant improvements in autism severity and intelligence quotient.
population_specificity: A single child with autism and epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory properties of Cat's claw, specifically its ability to protect against oxidant-induced stress and modify transcriptionally regulated events.
results_summary: Cat's claw attenuated peroxynitrite-induced apoptosis, inhibited iNOS gene expression, nitrite formation, and NF-kappaB activation, and reduced indomethacin-induced intestinal inflammation in rats.
population_specificity: In vitro cell lines (RAW 264.7 and HT29) and rats with induced intestinal inflammation.
effective_dosage: 100 µg/mL in vitro; 5 mg/mL in drinking water for rats.
study_duration: Not specified for in vitro; duration for rats not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ethanol and aqueous extracts of Cat's claw influence blood coagulation and platelet activation, and if they exhibit anticoagulant properties.
results_summary: The extracts showed slight antiplatelet activity and prolonged thrombin time, with the ethanolic leaf fraction being the most effective thrombin inhibitor. The study suggests potential for Cat's claw as a natural thrombin inhibitor.
population_specificity: Human platelet-rich plasma (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of medicinal plants, including Cat's claw, for their neuroprotective, anti-inflammatory, and cognitive-enhancing effects in Alzheimer's disease and pre-Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Cat's claw but suggests that medicinal plants, in general, hold promise for preventing and treating cognitive decline associated with Alzheimer's disease.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of studies on Alzheimer's disease and pre-Alzheimer's disease)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of systemic therapies, including Cat's claw, on the treatment of aromatase inhibitor-induced musculoskeletal symptoms (AIMSS) in women with stage I to III hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that Cat's claw showed a treatment effect with 95% CI that did not include a minimal clinically important difference (MCID) for pain relief in AIMSS, indicating limited efficacy. No serious adverse events were reported for Cat's claw or other systemic therapies.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with hormone receptor-positive stage I to III breast cancer experiencing AIMSS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Cat's claw interacts with antiretroviral drugs and affects their levels in patients.
results_summary: The study found that Cat's claw significantly increased the levels of antiretrovirals, suggesting patients should be monitored for adverse effects when taking this supplement alongside antiretroviral therapy.
population_specificity: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) patients taking antiretroviral drugs.
interactions: Increased levels of antiretrovirals when taken with Cat's claw.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight potential nephrotoxic effects of herbal therapies, including Cat's claw, due to limited toxicological studies.
results_summary: The study reported acute allergic interstitial nephritis diagnosed after intake of Peruvian Cat's claw, indicating potential kidney-related adverse effects. No efficacy data was provided regarding intended outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mention of adverse effects in humans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Uncaria tomentosa (cat's claw) gel as a topical treatment for denture stomatitis compared to miconazole and placebo.
results_summary: Cat's claw gel showed comparable efficacy to 2% miconazole gel in reducing denture stomatitis severity and Candida colony counts, with significant reductions observed after one week of treatment. The effects persisted one week post-treatment, and C. albicans was the most prevalent microorganism before treatment.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with denture stomatitis.
study_duration: 1 week of treatment, with follow-up one week post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Cat's claw, alone or in combination, for managing osteoarthritis (OA) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Three studies supported the use of Cat's claw for OA, either alone or in combination, but the abstract does not specify the extent of its efficacy. No support was found for its use in RA.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (OA) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential pharmacokinetic interactions between Cat's claw and antiretroviral drugs (PIs and NNRTIs) in HIV/AIDS patients.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that Cat's claw exhibited potentially significant pharmacokinetic interactions with protease inhibitors or non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors, based on in vitro studies and clinical reports. However, no specific clinical outcomes or efficacy data for Cat's claw were detailed.
population_specificity: HIV/AIDS patients in Southern Africa using traditional/complementary/alternate medicines alongside antiretroviral therapy.
interactions: Potential pharmacokinetic interactions with protease inhibitors (PIs) and non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize existing evidence on the neuroprotective mechanisms of Orthosiphon stamineus (Cat's whiskers) in Central Nervous System (CNS) disorders.
results_summary: The study identified protective effects of Cat's whiskers extracts on Alzheimer's disease, epilepsy, learning and memory, oxidative stress, and neurotoxicity, suggesting potential neuroprotective benefits for conditions like neurodegeneration and neuroinflammation. All findings were based on preclinical studies using animal models or in vitro systems.
population_specificity: Animal models and in vitro systems (preclinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a 50% ethanol extract of Orthosiphon stamineus (EOS) to treat rheumatoid arthritis by assessing its anti-inflammatory and anti-arthritic effects.
results_summary: EOS demonstrated dose-dependent inhibition of paw edema, suppressed inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1, COX-1, COX-2), improved joint integrity, and protected cartilage and soft tissue in arthritic models.
population_specificity: Arthritic rats and LPS-stimulated human macrophages (U937).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective potential of CDP-choline on dopaminergic neurons exposed to MPP(+) and glutamate toxicity.
results_summary: CDP-choline significantly increased the survival of dopaminergic neurons compared to controls and provided protection against MPP(+) and glutamate toxicity. It also reduced propidium iodide uptake, indicating decreased cell death.
population_specificity: Primary dopaminergic cultures from mouse mesencephala.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiapoptotic and antioxidant activities of Orthosiphon stamineus (Cat's whiskers) extracts and fractions, focusing on their effects against hydrogen peroxide-induced apoptosis in MDA-MB-231 epithelial cells.
results_summary: The study found that the ethyl acetate fraction (EAF) had the highest phenolic content, while the chloroform fraction (CF) had the highest flavonoid content. Cat's whiskers demonstrated dose-dependent inhibition of cell death, reduced caspase-3 activity, and modulated Bcl-2 and Bax expression, indicating anti-apoptotic effects.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 epithelial cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding oral CDP-choline to patching therapy improves visual function in children with amblyopia compared to patching alone.
results_summary: CDP-choline combined with patching did not show greater effectiveness than patching alone after 30 days but helped maintain visual acuity improvements at 90 days, unlike patching alone. Similar stability was observed in visual acuity measured by isolated letters.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-10 years with anisometropic or strabismic amblyopia.
effective_dosage: 800 or 1,200 mg daily (based on body weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic CDP-choline treatment improves functional recovery and neuronal plasticity after stroke.
results_summary: CDP-choline improved functional outcomes in stroke-affected animals, as shown by increased pellet consumption in the staircase test and reduced asymmetry in the EBST. It also enhanced dendritic complexity and spine density in the undamaged motor cortex.
population_specificity: Stroke-affected animals (middle cerebral artery occlusion model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how CDP-choline affects phosphatidylcholine (PtdCho) homeostasis and neuroprotection following transient focal cerebral ischemia.
results_summary: CDP-choline significantly restored PtdCho levels by attenuating PLA2 activity, sPLA2-IIA mRNA/protein levels, and PtdCho-PLC activity, while partially restoring CCT activity. It also reduced infarction volume by 55% after ischemia-reperfusion.
population_specificity: Animal model (transient middle cerebral artery occlusion, tMCAO)
study_duration: 1 hour of tMCAO followed by 1 day of reperfusion

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of CDP-choline and choline chloride on platelet, white blood cell, and red blood cell counts, as well as platelet function during endotoxemia in dogs.
results_summary: CDP-choline and choline chloride attenuated endotoxin-induced declines in platelet counts and improved platelet function, with CDP-choline blocking the shortening of platelet closure times. Both treatments showed statistically significant improvements compared to saline controls.
population_specificity: Dogs with induced endotoxemia.
effective_dosage: 70 mg/kg CDP-choline, administered intravenously three times at 4-hour intervals.
study_duration: Approximately 12 hours (three doses over 8 hours, with follow-up measurements up to 12 hours post-endotoxin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of CDP-choline liposomes in reducing cerebral infarction compared to free CDP-choline in a cerebral ischemia model.
results_summary: CDP-choline liposomes significantly decreased cerebral infarction by 62% compared to 26% for free CDP-choline, suggesting enhanced brain uptake and synergistic effects with phospholipid components.
population_specificity: Spontaneously hypertensive rats with induced focal cerebral ischemia and reperfusion.
study_duration: 1 hour of ischemia followed by 24 hours of reperfusion.

study_goal: To assess the efficacy of CDP-choline in treating cognitive, emotional, and behavioral deficits in elderly individuals with chronic cerebral disorders.
results_summary: CDP-choline showed no benefit on attention but demonstrated positive effects on memory function and behavior. The drug was well tolerated, with no significant safety concerns reported.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with cognitive impairment due to chronic cerebral disorders, ranging from subjective memory complaints to mild/moderate vascular dementia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (studies varied in dose and administration methods).
study_duration: Ranged from 20-30 days to 12 months across studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of CDP-choline in treating cognitive, emotional, and behavioral deficits in elderly individuals with chronic cerebral disorders.
results_summary: CDP-choline showed significant beneficial effects on memory function and behavior but no significant effect on attention. The drug was well tolerated.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with chronic cerebral disorders, particularly those with cerebrovascular disease.
study_duration: Studies ranged from 20-30 days, 6 weeks, 2-3 months, or continuous administration over 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how CDP-choline counteracts pro-inflammatory cytokine-mediated disruption of phosphatidylcholine homeostasis and its potential benefits in stroke treatment.
results_summary: CDP-choline may increase phosphatidylcholine levels by attenuating PLA(2) stimulation and loss of CCT activity, counteracting TNF-alpha and IL-1beta effects. Re-evaluation of phase III stroke trial data was encouraging, suggesting CDP-choline as a safe and well-tolerated agent for multi-drug stroke treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with brain ischemia (stroke)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether uridine enhances phosphatidylcholine (PC) synthesis by measuring CDP-choline levels in PC12 cells.
results_summary: Uridine (50-100 µM) increased UTP, CT, USAP, and CDP-choline levels in PC12 cells without affecting diacylglycerol synthesis or phosphotransferase activity, suggesting uridine may enhance PC synthesis in the brain.
population_specificity: Clonal PC12 rat pheochromocytoma cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of CDP-choline in treating cognitive, emotional, and behavioral deficits in older people with chronic cerebral disorders.
results_summary: CDP-choline showed modest but statistically significant benefits on memory function and behavior, with stronger evidence of improvement in global clinical impression. No significant effect was found on attention, and the drug was well tolerated.
population_specificity: Older people with cognitive impairment due to chronic cerebral disorders, particularly those with cerebrovascular disease.
study_duration: Ranged from 20-30 days to 3 months, with some studies using cycles of 2-3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different oral doses of CDP-choline on plasma levels of choline, cytidine, and uridine in mildly hypertensive subjects.
results_summary: Plasma choline and uridine levels increased dose-dependently, with choline remaining elevated for 5-10 hours and uridine for 5-6 hours. Cytidine levels were not reliably detectable, suggesting uridine and choline, not cytidine, are key substrates for brain phosphatide synthesis in humans.
population_specificity: Twelve mildly hypertensive but otherwise normal fasting subjects.
effective_dosage: 500 mg, 2000 mg, and 4000 mg orally once at 8:00 a.m.
study_duration: Single administration per treatment day, with plasma sampling over 12 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of CDP-choline in treating cognitive, emotional, and behavioral deficits in elderly patients with chronic cerebral disorders.
results_summary: CDP-choline showed modest but significant benefits on memory function and behavior, with stronger evidence of improvement in global clinical impression. No significant effect was observed on attention, and the drug was well tolerated.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with cognitive impairment due to chronic cerebral disorders, particularly cerebrovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the neuroprotective effects of CDP-choline in transient forebrain ischemia, specifically its impact on blood-brain barrier dysfunction, edema, and neuronal death.
results_summary: CDP-choline significantly attenuated blood-brain barrier dysfunction, reduced arachidonic acid and leukotriene C(4) synthesis, and provided 65% neuroprotection against hippocampal neuronal death. It also substantially reduced edema at 3-day reperfusion.
population_specificity: Gerbils with transient forebrain ischemia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of citicoline (500 mg bid) and determine if short-term treatment alters mood states and cocaine craving in subjects with a history of cocaine dependence.
results_summary: Subjects experienced no side effects, and citicoline treatment was associated with decreases in self-reported mood states linked to cocaine craving, suggesting potential benefits for cocaine dependence.
population_specificity: Subjects with a history of cocaine dependence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if CDP-choline could improve motor and spatial memory deficits after traumatic brain injury (TBI) and whether it increases acetylcholine release in the brain.
results_summary: CDP-choline improved post-TBI motor and spatial memory performance, reduced cognitive deficits in the Morris water maze, and attenuated scopolamine-induced memory disruption. It also increased acetylcholine release in the hippocampus and neocortex.
population_specificity: Rats with induced traumatic brain injury (TBI) and normal, awake, freely moving rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CDP-choline affects brain platelet-activating factor (PAF) levels in aged rats and its potential implications for central nervous system diseases.
results_summary: Aged rats had 67% lower PAF levels than young rats. Chronic CDP-choline treatment (500 mg/kg/day) reduced PAF levels by over 65% in aged rats after 8 days, stabilizing at these low levels with continued treatment, suggesting CDP-choline's effects may involve PAF modulation.
population_specificity: Aged (19-month-old) rats
study_duration: At least 8 days (exact duration not specified beyond stabilization)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of CDP-choline on brain choline metabolism in human subjects, particularly its impact on phosphatidylcholine synthesis in younger and older adults.
results_summary: CDP-choline increased plasma choline similarly in younger and older subjects, but brain choline resonance increased by 18% in younger subjects while decreasing by 6% in older subjects, suggesting age-dependent effects on phosphatidylcholine synthesis.
population_specificity: Younger (mean age 25 years) and older (mean age 59 years) human subjects.
effective_dosage: Single oral doses (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of chronic CDP-choline administration on neurosecretory neurons in aged mice, focusing on morphological and morphometric changes.
results_summary: CDP-choline treatment led to neuronal hypertrophy, increased cellular protein synthesis machinery, more neurosecretory granules, and reduced glial coverage, suggesting enhanced neurohormone synthesis. No tertiary lysosomes were observed in treated animals.
population_specificity: Aged mice (12 to 26 months old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological effects, safety, and therapeutic potential of CDP-Choline in treating cerebral vascular disease, head trauma, and cognitive disorders.
results_summary: CDP-Choline demonstrated neuroprotective effects, improved cognitive and memory performance, accelerated recovery from brain injuries, and enhanced cerebral metabolism without serious side effects. It also showed efficacy in treating Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease as co-therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with head trauma, acute cerebral vascular disease, chronic cerebral ischemia, Alzheimer's disease, and Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of CDP-Choline on cognitive and behavioral capabilities in patients with chronic cerebrovascular diseases.
results_summary: CDP-Choline significantly improved attention, memory, and behavioral control compared to placebo, with no reported side effects.
population_specificity: 92 patients with chronic cerebrovasculopathy (46 in each group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of CDP-choline on brain electrical activity and mental performance in Alzheimer's disease patients.
results_summary: CDP-choline reduced theta band spectral amplitude in specific brain regions and improved mental performance in early-onset AD patients, with no significant changes in late-onset AD patients.
population_specificity: 19 Alzheimer's disease patients (10 males, 9 females; age 66.21 ± 1.48 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of CDP-Choline (citicoline) as a treatment for stroke and other neurological disorders, focusing on its mechanisms of action and potential benefits.
results_summary: The study found that CDP-Choline provides choline and cytidine, which support phosphatidylcholine synthesis and neuronal membrane repair, potentially aiding stroke recovery. Pre-clinical and clinical data suggest it may also mitigate free fatty acid-induced toxicity from ischemic injury.
population_specificity: Patients with stroke, head trauma, and other neurological disorders (studied in Europe, Japan, and the U.S.).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CDP-choline reduces blood histamine levels in patients with early-onset and late-onset Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: CDP-choline reduced blood histamine levels by 2-fold in both EOAD and LOAD patients, with effects observed 2 hours after administration and progressively over 30 days. The results suggest CDP-choline may modulate immune responses linked to histamine in AD.
population_specificity: Patients with early-onset Alzheimer's disease (EOAD) and late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of CDP-choline on cognitive function and cerebral blood flow velocities in patients with Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: CDP-choline significantly improved MMSE scores in early-onset Alzheimer's patients and enhanced orientation subtests in the overall group. It also increased blood flow velocities in the middle cerebral arteries.
population_specificity: 20 patients with Alzheimer's disease (age 57-78 years, mean 66.75 ± 6.73).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CDP-choline could reverse age-related impairments in mitochondrial and synaptosomal membrane proteins in rat brains.
results_summary: CDP-choline treatment significantly increased the levels of several proteins that had declined with aging, suggesting a potential role in improving brain energy metabolism and nucleotide availability. The effects were attributed to enhanced cytidylic nucleotide availability and total adenine nucleotide content.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats aged 4, 12, 18, and 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CDP-choline could restore immune function and improve mental performance in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and multi-infarct dementia (MID) by influencing IL-1 beta production and other biological parameters.
results_summary: The study investigated CDP-choline's effects on cognition, biological parameters, and IL-1 beta production, suggesting potential benefits in restoring immune function and improving mental performance in dementia, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD) and multi-infarct dementia (MID).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of patients with severe or moderate head injury receiving conventional treatment versus those treated with CDP-choline.
results_summary: CDP-choline improved global patient outcomes, showing a trend toward greater improvement in motor, cognitive, and psychic alterations, and reduced hospital stay duration for severe head injury patients.
population_specificity: 216 patients with severe or moderate head injury

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of CDP-choline in reducing postconcussional symptoms and improving neuropsychological outcomes in patients with mild to moderate closed head injury.
results_summary: CDP-choline significantly reduced postconcussional symptoms compared to placebo (P < 0.005) and improved recognition memory for designs (P < 0.02), though other neuropsychological test results did not differ between groups.
population_specificity: Young men admitted to neurosurgery after mild to moderate closed head injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CDP-choline could counteract cognitive impairments associated with aging by increasing brain phospholipid levels and enhancing neurotransmission.
results_summary: The study found that CDP-choline increased phosphatidylcholine and related phospholipids in the brain, potentially improving memory deficits in patients with cerebral insufficiency, chronic cerebrovascular disease, and dementia.
population_specificity: Patients with cerebral insufficiency, chronic cerebrovascular disease, and dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic CDP-choline administration could reverse age-related declines in dopamine and acetylcholine receptor densities and brain membrane fluidity in aged mice.
results_summary: CDP-choline increased dopamine receptor densities by 11% (100 mg/kg) and 18% (500 mg/kg) and muscarinic receptor densities by 6% (100 mg/kg) and 17% (500 mg/kg) in aged mice, while also enhancing brain membrane fluidity. The treatment partially reversed age-related receptor declines without altering receptor affinities.
population_specificity: 19-month-old mice
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg/day and 500 mg/kg/day, incorporated into chow

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of CDP-choline in improving cognitive and behavioral parameters in patients with mild to moderate brain aging.
results_summary: CDP-choline significantly improved symptomatology after the first treatment cycle (p < 0.001), with further improvement in the second cycle (p < 0.001). The therapeutic effect persisted during the wash-out period, particularly for certain items on Plutchik's scale (p < 0.01).
population_specificity: 237 outpatients and inpatients with mild to moderate brain aging.
study_duration: Two 21-day treatment cycles with a one-week wash-out period between them.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CDP-choline could improve vigilance in rats under hypoxic conditions, simulating potential treatment for cerebral syndromes secondary to hypoxia in humans.
results_summary: CDP-choline demonstrated a protective effect by increasing vigilance in rats under mild hypoxia (15% O2), suggesting potential benefits for treating hypoxia-related cerebral syndromes. No significant adverse effects were reported, but the study did not assess safety in detail.
population_specificity: 48 Wistar rats exposed to progressively reduced oxygen levels (15% to 7% O2).
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg body weight, administered via food.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if CDP-Choline could improve symptoms of tardive dyskinesia (TD) based on the cholinergic-deficiency hypothesis.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of efficacy, adverse effects, or changes in psychopathology with CDP-Choline treatment in TD patients. The small sample size limited the power to detect a treatment effect.
population_specificity: Four women and one man with tardive dyskinesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discover and validate potential food exposure markers (PEMs) for chocolate in a mixed dietary background.
results_summary: The study identified unique PEMs for chocolate, reflecting its distinct composition rather than frequency or amount consumed. It also validated 23% of PEMs from a previous meal study.
population_specificity: 107 subjects randomized to two distinct dietary patterns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using chocolate spread as a vehicle for voluntarily ingested Temgesic (an analgesic) in a mouse model of anastomotic leakage.
results_summary: The study found that using absorbable sutures along with Temgesic in chocolate spread as an analgesic regimen was feasible in the mouse model, but the primary focus was on surgical outcomes, not chocolate's effects.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice
